title: Tito Vilanova
text:
Francesc "Tito" Vilanova Bayó (17 September 1968 – 25 April 2014) was a Spanish professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Midfielder%23Central%20midfielder">central midfielder</a> and <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a>.
After a career which consisted of a total of 26 <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> matches in three seasons, all with <a href="RC%20Celta%20de%20Vigo">Celta</a>, he went on to work with <a href="FC%20Barcelona">Barcelona</a> as an assistant coach under <a href="Pep%20Guardiola">Pep Guardiola</a>, being part of the squads that won 14 titles.
Vilanova was appointed first-team manager in 2012, <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20La%20Liga">winning the national championship in his only season</a>. He stepped down in July 2013 due to ill health, and died the following year from cancer.
Playing career.
Born in <a href="Bellcaire%20d%27Empord%C3%A0">Bellcaire d'Empordà</a>, <a href="Province%20of%20Girona">Girona</a>, <a href="Catalonia">Catalonia</a>, Vilanova emerged in the <a href="Cantera">youth ranks</a> of local <a href="FC%20Barcelona">FC Barcelona</a>, but left the <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> giants in 1990 unable to break through into the first team. His next club was also in his native region, <a href="UE%20Figueres">UE Figueres</a>, with the player helping to its best-ever <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Segunda División</a> classification in the <a href="1991%E2%80%9392%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">1991–92 campaign</a> (third place); the team would eventually face <a href="C%C3%A1diz%20CF">Cádiz CF</a> in the promotion play-offs, losing 3–1 on aggregate.
Subsequently, Vilanova moved to the top division with <a href="RC%20Celta%20de%20Vigo">RC Celta de Vigo</a>, but appeared rarely over three full seasons, returning to division two in 1995 and representing <a href="CD%20Badajoz">CD Badajoz</a>, <a href="RCD%20Mallorca">RCD Mallorca</a> – contributing ten matches as the <a href="Balearic%20Islands">Balearic Islands</a> side <a href="1996%E2%80%9397%20Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n">promoted to the top flight</a> – <a href="UE%20Lleida">UE Lleida</a> and <a href="Elche%20CF">Elche CF</a>, retiring in December 2001 with lowly <a href="UDA%20Gramenet">UDA Gramenet</a>.
During his time at Lleida, in a 1998 <a href="Copa%20Catalunya">Copa Catalunya</a> game against Barcelona, coached by <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Mourinho">José Mourinho</a> who swapped responsibilities with head coach <a href="Louis%20van%20Gaal">Louis van Gaal</a> during the tournament, Vilanova scored a goal, becoming the first player to net against a team directed by the Portuguese.
Coaching career.
Vilanova started his <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">coaching</a> career in <a href="2003%E2%80%9304%20Tercera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">2003–04</a>, being in charge of <a href="Tercera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Tercera División</a> side <a href="FC%20Palafrugell">FC Palafrugell</a> and suffering relegation to <a href="Primera%20Catalana">Primera Catalana</a>. After working as technical director at <a href="Terrassa%20FC">Terrassa FC</a> he was appointed assistant manager at <a href="FC%20Barcelona%20B">FC Barcelona B</a>, under manager <a href="Pep%20Guardiola">Pep Guardiola</a>, with the team in the fourth tier.
In the summer of 2008, after leading the reserves to <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Tercera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">promotion</a> to <a href="Segunda%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20B">Segunda División B</a>, Vilanova and Guardiola were assigned to the first team, replacing Dutch duo <a href="Frank%20Rijkaard">Frank Rijkaard</a> and <a href="Johan%20Neeskens">Johan Neeskens</a>. <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20La%20Liga">His first year</a> at the <a href="Camp%20Nou">Camp Nou</a> was the most successful in the club's history, with the side winning six major trophies and becoming the first in Spain to conquer the <a href="Copa%20del%20Rey">Copa del Rey</a>, league and <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> titles (<a href="Treble%20%28association%20football%29">the treble</a>) in the same season.
On 27 April 2012, at the press conference in which Barcelona confirmed Guardiola's departure, it was also announced that Vilanova would be his successor; on 15 June, he signed a two-year contract. The same year, <a href="Lionel%20Messi">Lionel Messi</a> revealed that Vilanova was the first coach at the club to trust him, and made him a starter for their under-16 teams. 
Vilanova managed to field 11 academy graduates at the same time in a league game against <a href="Levante%20UD">Levante UD</a> on 25 November 2012, after <a href="Dani%20Alves">Dani Alves</a> left with an injury early on and was <a href="Substitute%20%28association%20football%29">replaced</a> by <a href="Mart%C3%ADn%20Montoya">Martín Montoya</a>. His team went on to lose only eight competitive matches during <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20FC%20Barcelona%20season">the campaign</a>, scoring at least once in every league fixture and winning their 22nd domestic championship by a record margin of 15 points, totalling 100 in the process.
Health issues and death.
On 19 December 2012, Barcelona announced that Vilanova was suffering from <a href="parotid%20gland">parotid gland</a> cancer for the second time. He was first diagnosed on 22 November of the previous year. 
Vilanova underwent surgery on 20 December 2012, subsequently being in chemotherapy and radiotherapy treatment for around six weeks. Assistant <a href="Jordi%20Roura">Jordi Roura</a> took over as head coach, with Vilanova returning to the bench in late March 2013. 
On 19 July 2013, Vilanova resigned as Barcelona manager as he relapsed from his condition, stating that the related treatment was not compatible with the status of a professional manager. He died on 25 April 2014, due to complications from cancer, at the age of 45 after suffering a relapse the previous week.
Personal life.
Vilanova was married to Montse Chaure. The couple had two children, daughter Carlota and son Adrià, with the latter also being involved in Barcelona's youth system.
In 2013, while Vilanova was in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> for his cancer treatment, Guardiola was also living in the city on a <a href="sabbatical">sabbatical</a>. He was disappointed that Guardiola did not come see him stating, "He's my friend and I needed him, but he wasn't there for me."
